Limerick, Sask.

Dear Mr. Wilson:

This is to acknowledge with thanks the receipt of the partially completed pioneer questionnaire of the late Mr. William Hough Collings. Your thoughtfulness in taking the trouble to forward it to us is very much appreciated and it will be filed with others we have received as part of the permanent record of the history of the province.

Yours sincerely,

Lloyd Redwell
Archival Assistant

LIMERICK SASKATCHEWAN.

The Provincial Archivist,
Saskatoon Sask.

Dear Sir,

Re William Hough Collings. I regret to have to advise you that Mr Collings passed away on July 4th last. I have been cleaning up his lares and penates, and amongst them I find the enclosed partially completed questionnaire.

I am sending it along to you.

Yours very truly,

Charles Wilson.
A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details or describe the particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name William Houch Collings
2. Your address Foyers D'Yarrell Home, Gravelbourg, Sask., and Linwood, Sask., Canada
3. Date March 9, 1912
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Pavillion Place, Exeter, Devon, England
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Samuel J. Collings, Grocer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) April, 1903 A.D.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. Normandy Street, Alton Hampshire July 1902 to April 1903.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.) 39 years less 1 Month.
9. What were your reasons for coming West? A friend came to town before me, but as I had followed an outdoor trade I wanted an outdoor life, but as I had followed an outdoor trade nobody in my town would bother with me after starting at that.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) And a letter from Rev. Lloyd, after Bishop Lloyd.

   - Germany
   - England
   - Canada
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a child," etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - To find work
   - To find land
   - To find freedom
   - To find opportunity
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Radio? Or government information?)

Note: In my own words, I would say that after starting out, nothing in my own words.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   I'd paid my tickets before I told anybody.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   The Barr Colony, and 3000 persons.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Ship, Lake Manitoba, Beaver Line.
   Passed through afterwards to the C.N. Railway when passengers discharged.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   Met my chum at Wapella, but decided to continue to Saskatoon.
   Was advised by someone brought to Saskatoon, to advise us to return to Main Line and get work. Went to Moose Jaw.
   One of a number of men, resold my tent to colony, and bought ticket to Moose Jaw.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   One night at Immigration Shed Moose Jaw, then went to a farm at what is known as Belknap now for 1 year, worked 2 years for Son-in-Law and more or less near there.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   N.W. 9-3-W8 Later Limerick.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   Always in Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   Barber. Farming.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   I paid my tickets before I told anybody.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   The Barr Colony, and 3000 persons.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Ship, via Edmonton, Beaver Gris Railway when passed through afterwards to the C.W.R. Railway when he came from discharge.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   He met at Athabasca, but did not go to Edmonton. He advised also advised by someone to go and get work. Went to Hays, Yank, and to return to Ottawa, then sell my land to Colborne, and give of a number of men, result my land to Colborne, and bought ticket to Ottawa, Paul.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   First night at Prince Albert, then went to a farm at what is known as Bell Beach near Prince Albert, worked 2 years on for $20 a month.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   S.E. Dehmers Butte office.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
